docs.abstract: Today, four days after a cyclone devastated the lowlands of southeastern Bangladesh, thousands of peasant families on this tiny delta island were burying their dead and struggling for food and shelter in a landscape strewn with human corpses and carcasses of sheep and cattle.   A military helicopter arrived in Urir Char for the third day in a row, bearing food as well as plastic sheets for the peasants to use for temporary shelter.      Government Cautious on Toll    Urir Char was one of several delta islands ravaged last weekend when a cyclone - the term used in the Indian Ocean region for a hurricane - hit, washing thousands of people away in its fury. Although there have been random estimates and guesses that tens of thousands may have died in the storm, Government officials have remained cautious about the actual toll.
docs.lead_paragraph: Today, four days after a cyclone devastated the lowlands of southeastern Bangladesh, thousands of peasant families on this tiny delta island were burying their dead and struggling for food and shelter in a landscape strewn with human corpses and carcasses of sheep and cattle.

byline.original: By Steven R. Weisman, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: About 27,000 Government doctors, engineers and agriculture specialists went on strike today demanding withdrawal of some administrative measures they say affect their services.  The professionals are demanding better service facilities and withdrawal of a Government order placing services of rural doctors, engineers and agriculturists under the authority of the 460 rural subdistricts.
docs.lead_paragraph: About 27,000 Government doctors, engineers and agriculture specialists went on strike today demanding withdrawal of some administrative measures they say affect their services. The professionals are demanding better service facilities and withdrawal of a Government order placing services of rural doctors, engineers and agriculturists under the authority of the 460 rural subdistricts.

docs.abstract: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the President of Bangladesh, deployed troops at stations where the people will vote Thursday on whether they approve of his continuation in office until national elections can be held.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the President of Bangladesh, deployed troops at stations where the people will vote Thursday on whether they approve of his continuation in office until national elections can be held.

headline.main: Troops Are Deployed For Bangladesh Election
headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD;   Troops Are Deployed For Bangladesh Election

docs.abstract: Lawyers in Bangladesh began an indefinite boycott of courts today in a bid to force President H. M. Ershad to restore democracy and the powers of the judiciary.   They said in a statement that the boycott was designed to back demands by opposition political parties for an end to nearly three years of military rule and establishment of a civil government through free parliamentary elections next April.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers in Bangladesh began an indefinite boycott of courts today in a bid to force President H. M. Ershad to restore democracy and the powers of the judiciary.

headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD;   Bangladesh Lawyers Are Boycotting Courts

docs.abstract: The two main opposition leaders in Bangladesh, Begum Khaleda Zia and Sheik Hasina Wazed, were put under house arrest Saturday as part of a ban on political activity and a tightening of martial law instituted Friday by the President, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad.
docs.lead_paragraph: The two main opposition leaders in Bangladesh, Begum Khaleda Zia and Sheik Hasina Wazed, were put under house arrest Saturday as part of a ban on political activity and a tightening of martial law instituted Friday by the President, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad.

headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD;   Bangladesh Confines Opposition Leaders

docs.abstract: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad told the nation today that his martial-law Government would lift a 10-month ban on opposition political demonstrations Jan. 1.   General Ershad, Bangladesh's President, in a speech broadcast on the eve of Bangladesh's independence day, also said he would restore democracy and hold national elections as soon as possible.   ''My Government and I are firmly committed to the transition to democracy and constitutional rule,'' General Ershad said. ''It is my declared policy of having an elected Government within the shortest possible time.''
docs.lead_paragraph: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad told the nation today that his martial-law Government would lift a 10-month ban on opposition political demonstrations Jan. 1.

headline.main: BANGLADESH TO LIFT BAN ON RALLIES
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESH TO LIFT BAN ON RALLIES

docs.abstract: Workers at a jute mill near Dhaka called off a weeklong strike today after talks with President H. M. Ershad, the state radio said. Nearly 26,000 workers of the Adamjee jute mill went on strike over the deduction of advance pay given them in August. The police opened fire when several hundred strikers refused to leave the mill, and two workers were killed.
docs.lead_paragraph: Workers at a jute mill near Dhaka called off a weeklong strike today after talks with President H. M. Ershad, the state radio said. Nearly 26,000 workers of the Adamjee jute mill went on strike over the deduction of advance pay given them in August. The police opened fire when several hundred strikers refused to leave the mill, and two workers were killed.

docs.abstract: Anti-Government strikes by doctors, engineers, students and lawyers paralyzed several Government offices in Bangladesh today and prompted the closing of universities and colleges, officials said.    The officials said the Bangladesh Supreme Court was closed after senior lawyers, who were demanding an end to the military Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad and a return to civilian rule, staged a sit-in.    The police said the strikes were peaceful.
docs.lead_paragraph: Anti-Government strikes by doctors, engineers, students and lawyers paralyzed several Government offices in Bangladesh today and prompted the closing of universities and colleges, officials said.

headline.main: Strikes in Bangladesh Protest Military Rule
headline.print_headline: AROUDN THE WORLD;   Strikes in Bangladesh Protest Military Rule

docs.abstract: Voters turned out in large numbers today to choose local council chairmen in 252 rural subdistricts, despite a call for a boycott by the main opposition parties, local officials said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Voters turned out in large numbers today to choose local council chairmen in 252 rural subdistricts, despite a call for a boycott by the main opposition parties, local officials said.

headline.main: Bangladeshis Vote Despite Call for Boycott
headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD;   Bangladeshis Vote Despite Call for Boycott

docs.abstract: Gen. H. M. Ershad, the leader of Bangladesh, dissolved his Council of Ministers today and announced that parliamentary elections would be held April 6, the first in six years.   General Ershad, who decreed martial law after taking power in a bloodless coup in 1982, is expected to name a new Cabinet on Wednesday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. H. M. Ershad, the leader of Bangladesh, dissolved his Council of Ministers today and announced that parliamentary elections would be held April 6, the first in six years.

headline.main: Bangladesh Dissolves Cabinet and Sets Election
headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD;   Bangladesh Dissolves Cabinet and Sets Election
